TEI.2.document_title: D W Anthony to Stephen F Austin, 12-26-1832

barker_notes.barker_summary: D. W. Anthony to Austin, December 26, 1832. Discussing policy to be followed in seeking reform. His editorial policy.
barker_notes.barker_footnotes:
Anthony was editor of The Constitutional Advocate and Brassoria Advertiser, published at Brazoria. For some account of him and his paper see an article by the editor in The Southwestern Historical Quarterly, XXI, 137-139.
On Dec. 19, 1832, the ayuntamiento of Bexar adopted a strong address to the State Congress explaining the inconveniences which Texas suffered from its union with Coahuila and outlining a plan of reform. The ideas and phraseology are strongly suggestive of Austin, and it seems evident that he had much to do with its adoption. For a copy see Vicente Filisola, Memorias para la Historia de la Guerra de Tejas, I. 272-293. This note was written before Austin to Williams of December 6, 1832 (which see), was discovered.

*div1 type="summary"* *p*D. W. Anthony to Austin, December 26, 1832. Discussing policy to be followed in seeking reform. His editorial policy.*/p* */div1*
*div1 type="body"*
*p**location_mentioned*Austin*/location_mentioned*,*date_mentioned n="12-26-1832"> Decr, 26th [1832]*/date_mentioned**/p* *p*Dear Sir:*/p*
*p*I had hoped to find you here, or at least that you would have arrived during my stay, as the principal object of my visit was to obtain a title to the lands I have selected, etc.—which it seems could not be effected without your presence.*/p*
*p*If it be beyond the reach of your power and option, to extend the quantity of land to more than 1/4 of a League, will you have the goodness to assist me in obtaining a *location_mentioned*grant */location_mentioned*from such authority as is requisite, if you think an application for that purpose would not be fruitless. I perceive that either a discretion has been confided to you, of else by means of petitions etc, great inequality in the quantity of *location_mentioned*lands */location_mentioned*granted to different *person_mentioned*individuals */person_mentioned*has been effected, and I hope if there be any such capacity, either which you have, or may be obtained to increase the quantity of land which I may be entitled to receive, that you will not be reluctant to aid me in its acquisition*/p*,
*p*I have had the pleasure of seeing your letter of*date_mentioned n="12-20-1832"> 20th inst.*/date_mentioned* to the *person_mentioned*Central Committee*/person_mentioned*, with the contents of which communicating the result and success of your visit to *location_mentioned*Bexar*/location_mentioned*, I am highly delighted, I sincerely hope you may not be deceived in the constancy and firmness of the people with whom you have been in conference.*/p*
*p*I am much pleased with the state of feeling prevailing, and the prospect of effecting the great objects we have proposed for ourselves—but I do not see much harmony in the design of a remon- strance, which must include the idea of submission on conditions of redress, and contain the request of the people to govt, to grant a mitigation and redress of grivances—and at the same time that there should be going forward a solm and firm determination of the same people to form a *person_mentioned*separate government*/person_mentioned* and remedy the evils of which they complain,—and without any intention of turning back, or giving up that determination. Such I understand to be the actual state of things. The *person_mentioned*Central Comt*/person_mentioned*. have ordered a positive and unconditional call of a convention. The people with whom you have been in communication have remonstrated, and expect the same thing to be performed by the *person_mentioned*people */person_mentioned*and *person_mentioned*Authorities of the whole *location_mentioned*country*/location_mentioned**/person_mentioned*. Should what is complained of be listened to, and acted upon favourably by the present *person_mentioned*state Go[vt]*/person_mentioned* how will we stand, or how will we proceed? I hope you, and all of us will not be unable to solve the dilemma, when it presses itself upon us. But at present it has not a very seemly, or very sincere appearance. Let us make the good of our country our motto, and our highest maxim.*/p*
*p*I shall be glad to hear from you, which I should at any rate expect, as soon as you return. I look for *person_mentioned*Grayson */person_mentioned*every day, having lately heard from him, and with him I expect my *person_mentioned*brother*/person_mentioned*, etc. Their land affairs too, I hope you will not forget.*/p*
*p**person_mentioned*D W Anthony*/person_mentioned*.*/p*
*p*[Addressed] *person_mentioned*Col. Steven F. Austin*/person_mentioned* *location_mentioned* San Felipe*/location_mentioned**/p*
*/div1*
